author: Agency Staff
title: China likely to post capital account deficit | Asia-Pacific
text:
A Chinese national flag flutters on the Pearl River near a construction site in Guangzhou, Guangdong province, China. Picture: REUTERS Related articles China punishes ‘lazy’ officials for unspent funds China makes juggling act ever harder China issues reform plans for state-owned firms China will not have a hard landing, says Premier Li BEIJING — China is likely to continue to see a deficit on its capital and financial account in the second half amid global market volatility, the foreign exchange regulator said on Wednesday.
Separately, the central bank said it had increased gold holdings by 1% as the country that rivals India as the world’s largest bullion consumer seeks to diversify its foreign exchange reserves.
Concern over China’s economic slowdown and possible interest rate rises by the US Federal Reserve have fuelled a wave of capital outflows, which intensified after China’s surprising yuan devaluation in August.
China’s State Administration of Foreign Exchange (SAFE) said the expectation of a Fed interest rate rise and currency volatility in emerging markets would continue to affect international financial stability and fuel risk aversion.
"Looking at the domestic environment, the downward pressure persists in the process of economic transition, while domestic borrowing costs continue to decline," it said on its website.
China posted a deficit of $125.6bn on its capital account and financial account in the first half of 2015, including $40.6bn in the March-June quarter.
China had a current account surplus of $148.6bn in the first half, including $73bn in the second quarter, the regulator said in its international balance payment report.
China’s current account surplus in the first half was equivalent to 3.1% of gross domestic product (GDP), it said.
China would keep the yuan basically stable while improving management of its foreign exchange reserves to ensure safety, the regulator said.
It also said that the authorities would strengthen monitoring of cross-border capital flows.
Gold holdings
China’s gold hoard rose to 54.45-million troy ounces in August from 53.93-million ounces a month earlier, according to data released by the central bank on Wednesday. China ended six years of mystery surrounding the holdings in July, revealing a 57% jump since 2009 and overtaking Russia to become the country with the fifth-largest stash.
China has joined Russia and Kazakhstan in increasing gold assets and is reporting its position monthly, showing a shift towards greater transparency as the country improves data quality, increases its presence in commodities trading and promotes the international role of the yuan. The nation devalued its currency in August and announced a move to a more market-driven exchange-rate mechanism.
"It’s just a standard diversification," Morgans Financial analyst James Wilson said on Wednesday. "But it’s an inordinately small amount for the Chinese to be investing in at the moment, and that’s why we say that there should be a much bigger investment in gold from the Chinese purely because of the size of the economy."
China still has only about 1.6% of its foreign reserves in gold, compared with 73% for the US, 67% for Germany and 65% in France and Italy, World Gold Council data show.
Gold prices have lost about 40% from a record in 2011 and are trading near their lowest level in more than five years. The metal was at $1,126/oz on Wednesday.
Reuters and Bloomberg
